bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 168, Number 8 (Wednesday, January 12, 2022)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. SAN NICOLAS:H.R. 6388.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, clause 1 provides Congress with thepower to ``impose taxes and spend the money collected to paydebts and provide for the ``common defence'' and ``generalwelfare.''[Page H78]

item.title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022

latestAction.text: Returned to the Calendar. Calendar No. 144.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

item.fullName: Del. San Nicolas, Michael F. Q. [D-GU-At Large]

summary.text:
Combating Terrorist and Other Illicit Financing Act

This bill revises provisions related to the National Strategy for Combating Terrorist and Other Illicit Financing developed by the Department of the Treasury. Currently, the strategy must be published through 2022. The bill requires the strategy to be published in 2024 and 2026. The bill also revises how Treasury evaluates existing efforts as part of the strategy.

Additionally, tribal and territorial entities must be (1) eligible for grant programs to combat financial crime, and (2) included in efforts to combat illicit finance.

bill.title: Combating Terrorist and Other Illicit Financing Act

item.title: Combating Terrorist and Other Illicit Financing Act
Combating Terrorist and Other Illicit Financing Act
To make updates to the National Strategy for Combating Terrorist and Other Illicit Financing, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
